title: How to Dress a Newborn in Summer

steps.title: Dress your newborn in a single layer when the temperature is over 75 °F (24 °C).
steps.content: Dress your newborn in a single layer when the temperature is over 75 °F (24 °C). Consider what you yourself are comfortable wearing when it’s hot out and use that as a guide when you’re dressing your newborn in the summer. Choose outfits made of breathable cotton fabrics to keep your baby as comfortable as possible. [1] X Research source For example, if you’re comfortable wearing a T-shirt and shorts, chances are your baby will be, too. Short-sleeved body suits made of cotton are great options for your newborn. Dress them in whatever will be easiest to get on and off for all those diaper changes ! If your baby’s skin is flushed or if they are breathing rapidly, chances are they are too hot. Remove layers or take them indoors so they can cool down.

steps.title: Bring extra layers with you in case you’ll be in an air-conditioned room.
steps.content: Bring extra layers with you in case you’ll be in an air-conditioned room. Summertime can be a little tricky because outdoors, it might be 85 °F (29 °C) but inside, it could be 65 °F (18 °C). When you’re packing your newborn’s diaper bag, add a pair of long pants and a long-sleeved shirt or lightweight jacket. [2] X Research source Your baby will most likely need an extra layer when the temperature drops below 65 to 70 °F (18 to 21 °C). You’ll need extra layers if you’ll be outdoors when the temperature drops at night, too. Touch the back of your baby’s neck to determine if they’re too cold. If their skin is cool to the touch, you can add a layer to their outfit.

steps.title: Skip the socks to avoid overheating your newborn.
steps.content: Skip the socks to avoid overheating your newborn. Socks are really important during the colder months, but during the summer, they can contribute to overheating and dehydrating your newborn. If you want to put something on their feet, opt for sandals that allow their feet to breathe. [3] X Research source Your newborn can only sweat from their neck, hands, feet, and head, so covering their feet really decreases their ability to self-regulate their temperature. If you cover their feet, they can’t sweat through them.

steps.title: Use a lightweight floppy hat to protect your newborn’s skin from the sun.
steps.content: Use a lightweight floppy hat to protect your newborn’s skin from the sun. Pick a hat that has a floppy rim to give your newborn a little extra protection while you’ll be out in the heat. These hats are specifically made for babies to wear in the sun, and they are made of a breathable material that will help keep your baby cool. [4] X Research source Your newborn’s skin is really delicate and will burn much faster than your own skin will. Try to keep them out of direct sunlight as much as you can. Avoid using knit caps during the summer. The material isn’t very breathable and could make your baby too hot.

steps.title: Protect your newborn’s eyes with UV protection sunglasses.
steps.content: Protect your newborn’s eyes with UV protection sunglasses. Whether you’ll be driving in the car, sitting on the beach, or simply taking a walk with your newborn, keep their eyes sheltered from the sun as much as you can. Keep an extra pair in your diaper bag in case you lose a pair so your baby will always be protected. [5] X Research source Remember, your baby doesn’t know to not look directly at the sun and they can’t shade their eyes themselves, so you have to take care of this for them.

steps.title: Opt for a breathable sling or carrier if you wear your newborn.
steps.content: Opt for a breathable sling or carrier if you wear your newborn. When baby-wearing during the summer, keep in mind that your newborn will be absorbing your body heat. Dress them in minimal clothing (a simple onesie and no socks works great), and use a carrier or sling that is made of cotton. If you feel too hot in the carrier, chances are your baby is too hot. [6] X Research source Most brands have options for summertime or wintertime carriers to specifically keep your baby comfortable and safe.

steps.title: Dress your newborn simply
steps.content: Dress your newborn simply when it’s warm inside. If you don’t use air conditioning or if the temperature of the room is higher than 75 °F (24 °C), a light, single layer should be enough for your newborn to sleep comfortably. If the room is under 75 °F (24 °C), your newborn might need an extra layer. [7] X Research source If you don't have air conditioning, you can use a fan to help keep your newborn cool. [8] X Expert Source Julie Wright, MFT Parenting & Baby Sleep Specialist Expert Interview. 6 March 2020. If you use a standing fan in your newborn’s room, place it on the opposite side from where they’ll be sleeping. This will help regulate the temperature in the room but won’t disturb their sleep.

steps.title: Opt for a long-sleeved footed onesie for nighttime if your home is air-conditioned.
steps.content: Opt for a long-sleeved footed onesie for nighttime if your home is air-conditioned. Always pick pajamas made of cotton. If in the night, you find that your baby is too cold, simply add a lightweight swaddle. It might take a little bit of time to figure out what your baby likes best, but within a few weeks, you’ll be a pro at making your newborn comfortable at nighttime.

steps.title: Use a lightweight swaddle or sleep sack if you prefer to swaddle.
steps.content: Use a lightweight swaddle or sleep sack if you prefer to swaddle. Dress your baby in a simple onesie or leave them in their nappy, just depending on how warm the room is. Then secure a swaddle on top of that to wrap them up. [9] X Research source Never use free blankets in your newborn’s crib. They could accidentally cover your baby’s face in the nighttime.

steps.title: Put cotton mittens on your newborn’s hands to protect them from scratching.
steps.content: Put cotton mittens on your newborn’s hands to protect them from scratching. Newborn babies have sharp little nails and they don’t know yet to keep them away from their face. Opt for lightweight cotton mittens that fit snug on your baby’s hands so they won’t come loose during the night. [10] X Research source You can buy packs of mittens for $5 to $10 so you always have a clean pair for nighttime use.

steps.title: Keep your newborn’s head uncovered at night so they don’t overheat.
steps.content: Keep your newborn’s head uncovered at night so they don’t overheat. During the summertime, you can skip knit caps altogether for your newborn, whether it’s daytime or nighttime. Additionally, hats can pose a choking hazard at night for your baby, so it’s best to avoid them year-round for bedtime. [11] X Research source Also keep your newborn’s crib free of loose blankets, pillows, and stuffed animals, and these could also be dangerous. Newborns are often sent home from the hospital with a little cap on their head, but it's recommended that they stop wearing the cap after a few days so they're able to regulate their body temperature. [12] X Expert Source Julie Wright, MFT Parenting & Baby Sleep Specialist Expert Interview. 6 March 2020.

steps.title: Check your newborn’s temperature by touching the back of their neck.
steps.content: Check your newborn’s temperature by touching the back of their neck. Your little one might have cold hands and feet because their blood circulation is still developing, so they aren’t a good indicator of how warm your baby truly is. Use the back of their neck as a better gauge for their comfort level. If their neck is sticky or hot, they’re too warm. If their neck is dry to the touch and cool or slightly warm, they are comfortable. [13] X Research source When you check on your newborn during the night for feedings and diaper changes, check their temperature, too. This will happen once every 2 to 3 hours, depending on their feeding schedule.
